greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = n / gcd(n,5).
comment: As well as being a multiplicative sequence, a(n) is also strong divisibility sequence, that is, gcd(a(n),a(m)) = a(gcd(n,m)) for n, m >= 1. In particular, a(n) is a divisibility sequence: if n divides m then a(n) divides a(m). _Peter Bala_, Feb 20 2019
link: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,0,0,0,2,0,0,0,0,-1).
formula: a(n) = n/5 if 5|n, otherwise a(n) = n.
a(n) = A109046(n)/5. Dirichlet g.f.: zeta(s-1)*(1-4/5^s). - _R. J. Mathar_, Apr 18 2011
If gcd(n, m) = 1 then a(a(n)*a(m)) = a(a(n)) * a(a(m)), a(a(a(n))*a(a(m))) = a(a(a(n))) * a(a(a(m))) and so on.
mathematica: f[n_]:=Numerator[n/(n+5)]; Array[f,100] (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Feb 16 2011*)
program: (Sage) [lcm(n,5)/5 for n in range(1, 51)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 07 2009
(PARI) { for (n=1, 1000, write("b060791.txt", n, " ", n / gcd(n, 5)); ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Jul 12 2009
xref: Cf. Sequences given by the formula n/gcd(n,k) =  numerator(n/(n + k)): A026741 (k = 2), A051176 (k = 3), A060819 (k = 4), A60789 (k = 6), A106608 thru A106612 (k = 7 thru 11), A051724 (k = 12), A106614 thru A106621 (k = 13 thru 20).
results.author: _Len Smiley_, Apr 26 2001
